We pass to the fair in Bamwell which had been granted to the Priory. It soon gave rise to disputes between the Canons and the Burgesses of Cambridge„ For example, who is entitled to the catalla selonum-the chattels oi people who commit felony in the fair? The Canons, in spite of what they regarded as a precedent in their favour- a case which involved a pictoresque abjuration of the realm (p. 89l-had to give way, fearing ‘to lose their fair' by reason of an ‘abuse' of the franchise So they came to terms with the townsfolk. So far as we know the townsfollr themselves had no chartcred right to the catalla salonam before the reign of Richard 111. lt is to be remembered, however, that Bamwell and the scene of the fair lay within the boundaries of the town (vr‘lla) of Cambridge, and ‘the town' had been granted as a whole- in some sense or another-to the burgesses.

Cambridge, like other towns of the same class, was treated for one important purpose as though it were part of the ancient demesne of the Crown. The King could tallage it. Some documents are now given which set before us a question of ‘double taxation’ (pp. 91-2l The assessore of the tallage first tax the Prior's tenants in Cambridge ac· cording to their wealth in movables (per nurchandrirs suas), and then proceed to tax the Prior on the rents that those tenants pay him. He succeeds in asserting that this is not equitable; but has to obtain writs to the sheriff in 1252, 1254 and 1269.

The burgesses in a collective or corporate fashion owed a rent to the Priory; not a large rent, only ten shillings (p. 93). This was a fragment of arent of ,gro wherewith the burgesses had compounded for ‘the third penny of the borough’ due of old time to the Earl. By various gifts
